Review: The Secret Life of Pets (2016)
Released by Illumination Entertainment (not DreamWorks), The Secret Life of Pets is a charming animated feature that explores what our pets might be doing when we’re not around. The story follows Max, a pampered house dog, and Duke, a scrappy stray who ends up at Max’s home. After an unexpected turn of events, the two find themselves forced to work together—despite their initial dislike for one another.

The film’s concept is both clever and family-friendly, offering plenty of humor and heart. The animation is vibrant and well-executed, and the cityscapes are especially detailed and lively. The director kept the pacing tight and the story accessible for audiences of all ages.

While some of the voice casting choices didn’t entirely work for me—certain voices felt mismatched with their characters—I still found the film enjoyable overall. It’s lighthearted, fun, and sets itself up nicely for future installments.

The Secret Life of Pets may not reinvent the wheel, but it delivers a delightful experience with just enough originality to stand out. A cute film worth watching, especially for families and animal lovers.
